name: Teach the World Foundation
mission: Our mission is to solve the world's illiteracy problem by establishing and deploying effective and scalable models of literacy and learning, through pow...
theoryOfChange: Teach the World Foundation (TTWF) operates under a 'hybrid business model that combines social impact with strategic partnerships to enhance educational access and quality for out-of-school children'. Their approach is rooted in delivering innovative educational solutions through public-private partnerships, direct engagement with donors, and a franchising model. They have a detailed 'LEARNING MODEL' that utilizes digital, game-based learning technologies to address challenges in educational access, quality content, and teacher shortages. This model involves implementing programs with 'facilitators' at a 1-to-25 facilitator-to-student ratio, using commercially available tablets and award-winning game-based applications. TTWF also employs a 'MicroSchool model' which is an innovative solution to bring learning opportunities to underserved communities, equipped with tablets featuring gamified e-learning applications. They conduct independent research studies and use assessment tools, such as those validated by the Center for Economic Research in Pakistan (CERP), to measure the impact of their model on student learning, showing significant improvements in literacy and numeracy. Their ELAN solution is designed for scalability and adaptability, aiming to generate comprehensive insights into learning progress and application effectiveness to facilitate targeted improvements in content and teaching strategies, and to measure impact accurately.

evaluationSources: Center for Economic Research in Pakistan (CERP) assessment tools

zakatClaimEvidence: The official website and donation pages of Teach the World Foundation (US-based) do not explicitly mention accepting zakat donations, dedicated zakat funds, or zakat campaigns. (Source: https://www.teachtheworldfoundation.com/donate)

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization is identified as Sadaqah-eligible, offering a medium donor fit for those prioritizing educational literacy within a religious or cultural context [4][5]. While it addresses the urgent cause of global illiteracy, its specific alignment with traditional donor pathways is considered moderate [5].
dimension_explanations.impact: The foundation demonstrates high impact through capacity building, with a cost per beneficiary of 354.998 and a program expense ratio of 78.0% [1][5]. Pilot programs have shown measurable success in literacy metrics, including nursery rhyme singing and English reading direction.

strengths: High program expense ratio of 78.0%, ensuring the majority of funds reach educational initiatives
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.02 to raise every $1
Evidence-based approach with documented improvements in English alphabet recitation and writing

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects verified outcome data from a Nielsen proof-of-concept study showing significant literacy improvements.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: TTWF uses digital tablets and gamified software to enable self-learning and teacher-led digital instruction in areas lacking traditional schools.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the digital tools actually translate into recitation and writing skills for children.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a small revenue base of $254,278 and a scalable digital model, the foundation has significant capacity to absorb more capital.

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates remarkable lean operations, <cite id="5">spending only $0.02 per $1 raised</cite> of revenue, which is significantly better than industry averages.
Independent evaluations show significant gains, including <cite id="2">43% proficiency in English alphabet writing</cite> for intervention students versus only 11% for those in traditional settings.
The foundation maintains a <cite id="5">100% independent board</cite> and holds a Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid.

strengths_deep_dive: The foundation's impact is anchored by its 'Microschool' model, which has shown <cite id="3">100% success in teaching English reading direction</cite> (left to right) among early learners. This digital-led pedagogy is supported by a <cite id="5">78.0% program expense ratio</cite>, which, while slightly below the <cite id="5">peer median of 89.6%</cite>, remains highly effective for a growth-stage organization. Their commitment to transparency is further evidenced by a <cite id="5">perfect 100 score in several Charity Navigator accountability metrics</cite>, including the presence of a conflict of interest policy and whistleblower protections.
rich_narrative.summary: Teach-the-World Foundation Inc (TTWF) is a digital-first educational non-profit <cite id="1">founded in 2016</cite> with a mission to solve global illiteracy through scalable, technology-driven learning models. The organization operates primarily in <cite id="2">Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Malawi</cite>, deploying three core delivery channels: Microschools, InSchool programs, and AtHome learning. By leveraging digital tablets and gamified software, TTWF bypasses traditional infrastructure barriers to provide quality education in underserved regions. The foundation maintains a <cite id="5">three-star rating from Charity Navigator</cite> with an <cite id="5">overall score of 84/100</cite>, signaling a high degree of accountability and transparency. Financially, the organization reported <cite id="1">$254,278 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. A hallmark of their operational model is extreme efficiency in resource mobilization, <cite id="5">spending only $0.02 to raise every $1</cite> in public support. Their impact is grounded in empirical data; a Nielsen proof-of-concept study demonstrated that students in their programs achieved <cite id="2">95% proficiency in English alphabet recitation</cite> compared to just 58% in control groups. This evidence-based approach allows the foundation to maintain a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 78.0%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor contributions directly fund educational interventions rather than administrative overhead.
